title: 7-Eleven founder, chief resign in wake of pay scal | Business News | Business and Finance News | |
text:
THE founder and chairman of embattled convenience store chain 7-Eleven, Russ Withers has resigned.
Mr Withers and chief executive Warren Wilmot resigned today after weeks of revelations about 7-Eleven stores chronically underpaying international students.
Mr Withers also resigned from the Australian Olympic Committee over the scandal.
But Mr Withers will stay chairman of the group holding company that owns 7-Eleven and Starbucks stores.
“Naturally this is a major decision for me to stand aside as chairman, however I will continue to be a shareholder and I am determined to make sure the company is in the right hands to move forward,” Mr Withers said in a statement.
Mr Withers said he had planned to step down in 18 months time but it was right to move on now.
Mr Wilmot resigned after the extent to which franchisees had underpaid workers was revealed.
“Mr Wilmot acknowledged it would be difficult for him to play a central role in navigating the company through the current challenges it faces given his long standing executive role,” the statement said.
The company had come under increasing pressure after an investigation uncovered that some staff across the 620-store network had been working for as little as $5 an hour.
International students say they were only paid half their minimum wage and were threatened with deportation if they reported it.
In response, 7-Eleven had pledged to revise its business model after franchisees had savaged head office over the bad publicity and poor income levels of certain stores.
It had also appointed Allan Fels, the former boss of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, to head an independent company-funded panel to identify underpaid workers and repay their missing wages.
Former iiNet and West Coast Eagles chairman Michael Smith has been appointed chairman, while Bob Baily has been appointed interim CEO.
Mr Smith will lead the search for a new chief executive.
7-Eleven was understood to have been planning to roll out an additional 40 stores this financial year.
In the year to June 2015, the company generated earnings before interest and tax of $144 million.
 7-Eleven founder, chief resigns
